ZT2Strings.LOC_STRING: Beaver Lodge

Beavers construct the beaver lodge from sticks, twigs and branches placed in their exhibit.
Beavers
enter the lodge by swimming into the entrance.
Cubbing Den

A cubbing den is a warm, quiet enclosure that certain female animals will use to give birth. It is used by
bears,
pandas
and
gorillas.
Animals that give birth in cubbing dens are less likely to become ill.
Elephant House
This large, roomy concrete structure is designed to accommodate the particularly large mass of the elephant
Elevated Nest Box
The elevated nest box is a small house-like shelter mounted on a tall pole, which satisfies the needs of animals who like to nest above the ground.
Giraffe House
This tall building is designed to accommodate the extra height requirements of the tall giraffe.
Ground Nest

A ground nest, which is really nothing more than a large pile of leaves, is a comfortable resting place for many animals.
For many animals, including the gorilla, building a nest is a highly instinctual activity.
Hollow Tree Stump

Both the giant panda and the red panda consider a tall, hollow tree stump to be a very natural and inviting form of shelter. Guests enjoy seeing animals use shelters that more closely represent natural habitats.
Concrete Shelters

The large concrete shelter is a man-made structure that provides a restful environment and maximum protection for animals that prefer to sleep in an enclosure, including tigers, cheetahs, and most bears. Up to 2 animals may sleep in the small concrete shelter and up to 4 animals are accomodated by the large concrete shelter.
Rock Cave

The large rock cave, which includes a hole in the roof to ensure adequate ventilation, provides a natural habitat for animals, including the polar bear and cheetah, who prefer a dark, enclosed resting environment. The small cave accomodates 2 animals, and the large cave holds 4.
Snowy Rock Cave

The large snowy rock cave, which includes a hole in the roof to ensure adequate ventilation, provides a natural habitat for animals, including the penguin and the polar bear, who are comfortable in frigid, dark, and enclosed resting environments. The small cave accomodates 2 animals, and the large cave holds 4.
Stables

A wooden building contains stalls bedded with straw, providing a comfortable enclosure for hooved animals. An exterior overhang provides shade and protection from the elements. The small stable has 2 stalls and the large stable has 4.
Wooden Shelters

This man-made structure provides protection for animals that prefer to sleep in an enclosure. Up to 2 animals may sleep in the small wooden shelter and up to 4 animals can sleep in the large wooden shelter.
Raised Sleeping Platform
A raised platform with wooden ramps allows animals to walk up and sleep in a more protected position off the ground.
Shade Structure
This simple structure provides animals with a place to seek shelter from the sun.
Sleeping Basket

A basket primarily used by primates. One large animal or two small ones can fit comfortably into the basket. The basket can be made more restful if bedding material is placed in the exhibit. Bedding material will deteriorate over time.
